instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2159: What is A2159? A2159 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2019 with EMC 3301, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01598..
definitions.820-01598: What is 820-01598? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U6903: What is U6903? This chip is responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H in 2016-2018 model Macbook logic boards.
definitions.3V3_G3H_RTC: What is 3V3_G3H_RTC? 3V3_G3H_RTC Is an abbreviation of PP3V3_G3H_RTC which is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power rails rapidly cycling
threads.message: this board had a shorted <CHIP>U6903</CHIP>. it was pulling to ground both <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> and ppbus. i replaced it but now the rails are quickly cycling.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power rails rapidly cycling
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power rails rapidly cycling
threads.message: with those resistors removed the rail is 0v but <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC_REG_R</SIGNAL> is stable at 3.3v and ppbus is stable at 12.37v

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power rails rapidly cycling
threads.message: What is diode mode to ground reading at pin 1 of these resistors?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power rails rapidly cycling
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power rails rapidly cycling
threads.message:
Check diode mode to ground on all coils around <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>.
Also check all MLB's big coils.
Compare readings with good board.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power rails rapidly cycling
threads.message: diode mode to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is 0.228.   I injected voltage and <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> gets warm. <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> has 0.0000 ohms resistance to pin 1 of L7810. i've reattached <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> and nothing changed

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power rails rapidly cycling
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power rails rapidly cycling
threads.message: once i realized that <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> had a direct path to L7810 i reballed it twice to make sure that it wasn't a solder issue

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power rails rapidly cycling
threads.message:
How can a massage helps to a wooden foot???

CHANGE <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power rails rapidly cycling
threads.message: i've changed it with a known good one and now <SIGNAL>PP3V3_GH_PMU_VDDMAIN</SIGNAL> is a steady 3.3v but none of the coils have a voltage reading that is  steady. i'm seeing pulsing on the coils. the resistance to ground on all of them seems reasonable

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power rails rapidly cycling
threads.message:
Do you mean the big MLB's coils, or <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>'s coils?

Test if can enter into DFU...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power rails rapidly cycling
threads.message: the coils surrounding <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> have no steady value.  they're 0v but they pulse every few seconds

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power rails rapidly cycling
threads.message:
Both USB-C ports have the same behavior?

Be sure <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> is properly soldered.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power rails rapidly cycling
threads.message: yes both ports have the same behavior i've attached <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> a few times to be sure

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power rails rapidly cycling
threads.message:
Then T2 is damaged.
Has been overvolted through L7810.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power rails rapidly cycling
threads.message: i have another one of these boards but someone tore the board when removing the heatshield of the <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> and so now it get no s5 rails. <SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> is 3.3v.  where is <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> created on this board?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power rails rapidly cycling
threads.message:
The equivalent of <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> from old models is <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> on this board, page 68.

Actual <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> on this model, is a much low power rail.
It is generated by <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>, page 71.
